name: 2017_04_humanities_student_major_192_biology
title: 2017-04-humanities-student-major_192_biology.txt
content_scrubbed:
I got my PhD and did TA'ing at a top 15 private university, taught at a small liberal_arts school, worked a few semesters at a community college, and am now teaching at a public university that[.] known more for its sports than its academics. The prestige of the university does not directly correlate with the quality of the instruction. Really, the highest concentration of good teachers was at the small liberal_arts school, but there are excellent and horrible teachers at every level of education.

The main difference I saw was in the type of students. At every institution, there were 3 main types of students: the superstars, the workers, and the warm bodies. Really good schools have a higher percentage of superstars which allows professors to use more intensive (and interesting) approaches, but the best schools also have a stronger sense of entitlement in the warm bodies section. Community colleges are mostly workers and warm bodies, but I met superstars who were just as amazing as those at the highest level schools.

You're asking about perception, which is a different matter than what I've described above. Most schools would recognize that there[.] a range of great prospective students from different prestige levels of the schools, but there[.] always the lazy or prejudiced individual who will base their judgement on the name of the school.
